Posts.Content: Well done for not ignoring your symptoms scary though it is. If only we had the ability to know ourselves if we have cancer or not. We have to leave it to mammograms and biopsy.   The biopsy I didn't find to bad a friend had explained what had happened to her so I knew what to expect. It was really like a big pen that clunked when pressed and I felt no pain just a bit sore the next day. What I didn't expect was the waiting for the results all though I think being told I would have to ask my surgeon about going on holiday 2 months later kind of gave the game away!! Anyway here I am after lumpectomy and radiotherapy almost 2 years later and feeling great. Breast cancer is very treatable and if this is your case know that your team will act quickly and do their very best to give you a good outcome. For all we know it's a cyst and nothing to worry about but of course that won't stop the niggles of fear. So hang on in there remember the positives it could be nothing and if it's something it can be treatable. For now be kind to yourself and try distracting tactics anything to keep your mind off it. There are lots of us on this site who have been where you are we all try and support one another. So wishing you the best positive outcome. Que serra questions serra  Hugs Pearl
Posts.Title: Anxious - is it cancer?

Posts.Content: Hello just little me you may have all ready had lots of replies but would just like to ado things I found helpful.  I had my lumpectomy and WLE in April last year 13 lymph nodes removed with one cancerous . I didn't have a seed put in but a wire was put in on the day of operation to guide the surgeon. Sounds horrific but honestly never felt a thing and could even laugh As with the dressing on I looked like madona with the big pointy booby!  Recovery is different for all of us but heavy lifting should be avoided as you'll have stitches inside and out. Listen to what advice your surgeon and nurse give you. You will have a drain in place from the wound again no problem it's like a light tube going into a bottle this is usually  removed before going home. I used to put my bottle in the next sink to wash my hands:-)). If possible take a lightly padded cushion with you ,a heart shape one is ideal, as this helps with the seat belt for travelling home. Also found it great for keeping the underarm away from my body. It's very important that you go home having been given arm excercises this is to prepare you for radiotherapy as you need to be able to raise both arms above your head. If for some reason your not given these instructions or told about them do ask your nurse. I was put on the bum (bowel ) ward after my op and was given no excercises to follow fortunately I knew I needed them so my bcn sent them out to me. Yes it's sore but nothing you can't handle and it does heal and you move on very quickly then your onto the next stage.  Take it a step at a time and each step takes you nearer to being a neddy ( no evidence of disease )  Good luck I'll be thinking of you. Your stronger than you know. HUGS PEARL
Posts.Title: After sentinel lymph node biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi anyone out there taking exemestane 25 mg.? I was put on these after I had a rash with letrozole  find my left elbow is sore and achy! My canicer was on right side.
Posts.Title: Exmestane

Posts.Content: Decisions decisions so hard  to know what to do. I had 13 lymph nodes removed one cancerous so clearance definitely a good thing. Lymph nodes are in various places around the body so yea I still have some left. I try to be careful with that arm and apart from a slight numbness underneath the arm feel fine. I was borderline  for chemo and oncologist said the 3% extra security wasn't worth putting me through it. At the time I agreed with her however since then doubts have crept in as to whether I've done the right thing but convince myself shes the oncologist and must know her onions sort of speak. For me the clearance was a no brainer just get rid it had done it's job moping up chuck it out. After what you have been through its another mountain to climb and face but your strong and able to get through it . Everyone wants the best possible outcome and your team is working to give you a fighting chance to kick cancer butt. Prepare a heart pillow for after surgery it's good for resting under the arm and undER the seat belt and to cuddle at anytime. Use this site we are routing for you best wishes hang in there.xx
Posts.Title: Advice on Axillary Lymph Nodes Dissection / Lymph Nodes Removal

Posts.Content: Good idea I'm sure they'll want to see you and then all parties will know if it's something or nothing. Better safe than sorry. I swear to god I am never going to ignore anything and I've promised myself to stop self diagnosing!! Something I think we are all guilty of. That way I might avoid the lines of worry. Will be rooting for you x
Posts.Title: Under-arm pain

Posts.Content: It's hard sometimes  to be positive the surgery is over then bang another  hurdle but honestly it does improve.. I had four seromas drained in a short space of time didn't know I produced so much liquid!! Don't hesitate to go back if you feel you need to the nurses will soon tell you what needs doing. The hurdles get less and easier to manage. Keep exercising your arms It really does help with the radiotherapy  and be kind to yourself.Know a lot of us have been where you are and all though not everyone is the same we are here to minimise fear and help answer any questions .To the ladies and men out there  battling and wining this dratted disease   it's onward and upward
Posts.Title: 18 days post surgery and very sore / tender

Posts.Content: Hi bowbell,  poor you . I was put on letrozole by my oncologist and developed a itchy drive you mad rash:-(( My GP stopped all medications until we could find out the cause. Scary because I felt I had no protection from the cancer returning I contacted my oncologist to check I was doing the right thing and to inform her of my reaction. I have since seen her and been put on exemestane which all though have side effects I cross fingers don't have an allergic reaction to. Using this site I have learnt that different brands of the same tablet suit various people eg exemestane accord brand seems to suit me better and I have just asked my pharmacist if he can get that one in for me. I don't know if it's the same for letrozole but ask your oncologist or bc nurse for advice  hopefully they can help. All of the tablets have side effects it's finding the one that you can cope with. Good luck and hope your able to get a good sleep soon.
Posts.Title: Water retention and letrozole

Posts.Content: Chance 1960 good morning I was diagnosed 2015  had lumpectomy and radiotherapy and have had tender rib just under the breast , tenderness under the arm but not ear scar and a swelling between collar bone and shoulder bone. Like you I went to my GP who advised I go back to breast clinic. Which I did consultant checked me out thought there was no reason to worry but to put my mind at rest booked an ultrasound which yea proved him right no reason to worry. The point I'd like to make is they were happy to see me and didn't consider it a waste of their time they actually said they would  prefer to see me than have me worry. So get in touch with your breast nurse they may fit you in quicker than via docters. I'm hoping all is OK for you I'm sure a lot of it is after effects of treatment. It's the unknown that destroys our strength with knowledge we can cope and be stronger. Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Under-arm pain

Posts.Content: Great that you have your appointment. Like you we were due to go on holiday in Europe for two weeks . Saw consultant first who said he thought there was nothing to worry about and ultrasound arranged a couple of days after getting back with follow up appointment to discuss results. We went on holiday with an easy mind I thought if there was anything there they would advise me not to go. We also knew that if things went pear shape we could get back to uk fairly quickly driving if necessary. I know it's a different country but I'm sure if necessary they would step up to the mark. So get Thursday out the way and go enjoy your much needed break. Let me know how you get on . Buenos noches x
Posts.Title: Under-arm pain

Posts.Content: Hi warrior well I had my lumpectomy and WLE  in April and I had one node out of 14  that was positive and like you thought chemo was the only way to go. Talking to oncologist  as I was borderline for chemo treatment I honestly  didn't know which way to go! Told her it was a  decision I found hard to make and would like to be guided by her.  So no chemo but 15 sessions of rads and letrozole and I have to trust we made right decision. I was well and truly zapped and the precision the radiologist take in making sure you are in the right position is very reassuring. We all have doubts and dark thoughts that we haven't got rid of the beast but have to try and put that behind us I  have friends who have gone through the same and they are still here 20 years later. There are no garantees in life so I try to enjoy and take each day as it comes because I'm  still here and standing. I  have a breast that's a different colour tattoos that look like black heads and it's dinted but I'm here to tell the tale. Be positive enjoy life and trust all will be well. Moisturise moisturise and try and lift your arms above your head and your on your way. Good vibes to you and yours xx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy with W L E with one node positive

Posts.Content: Hi blossom 2 your obviously concerned about this pain so I feel you need reassurance perhaps from a referal. I had breast pain shooting pains around my nipple and very uncomfortable under arm down the side where a wire would be in a bra. Went to docs twice he couldn't feel anything and as I had a mammogram appointment in 2 months time just kept trying different bras. Spent a small fortune! ! Anyway at mammogram  told breast pain is not associated with breast cancer. Hey ho a recall and yes I had certainly caught cancer . However as it was caught early completely treatable. That was in April 2015 and after a lumpectomy, node clearance, radiation and exemestane tabs I'm still here.  The pain could have been coincidence but I ignore nothing now and if I'm at all concerned I go and get checked out. A day of worry is a day wasted. Hoping your fears and questions are answered soon. Wishing you well Hugs Pearl xx
Posts.Title: Breast pain - what would you do?

Posts.Content: Hi worried 2016 it sounds as though it may be a seroma this is because the lymph glands drain and move fluid around the body but yours have been removed so the fluid has to re learn where it can go to. I had three seromas and they were drained each time. I would honestly get it checked out rather than worrying  it's the unknown that turns a pimple into a mountain. Dont wait for the storm to pass dance in the rain. I'm 18 months since my op and it feels like a dream you will get there honestly. Best wishes hugs Pearl
Posts.Title: Lump under arm after op

Posts.Content: Its funny how our emotions catch us out when we least expect it. I've just had my second mammogram and honestly so nervous I kept having to run to the loo it's a wonder I didn't miss it!! My recent blub was last week over a skin tag that has to be removed. I was fine until the consultant said it would be sent for biopsy and if found cancerous it would involve more surgery. Hardly heard the bit that he thought it was benign!! Filled up with tears and apologised explaining I'd had breast cancer and the possibility of another cancer I found quite emotional. His reply of it won't be the same cancer doh! Made me realise we are a unique bunch only we can get the see saw of emotions so your not alone cry,rant , laugh this is the place to do it. After all we are human. Onwards and upwards Pearlxx
Posts.Title: Feelings

Posts.Content: All good advice but one thing I would take is a heart shaped cushion or any cushion . It really helps when your ready to come home as it keeps the seat belt away from the surgery site. Also found it very useful after node removal placed under my arm it stopped the close contact of under arm to side body. It's good for hugging when you need it. One step at a time and I'm sure you'll get there. Your one step nearer to dealing with this critter. Wishing you the most positive of outcomes and a quick recovery. Be kind to yourself and take it a day at a time.  Hugs Pearl
Posts.Title: What to take to hospital?

Posts.Content: Brilliant I was diagnosed April 2015 thought I was going to have chemo so being proactive asked my lovely hairdresser to cut it very short. Loved it no chemo needed but still get my hair cut very short it's actually a man's cut and she shaves the back with no 2 I think. It's so easy it doesn't move I literally wash and go. I do sometimes get the look but hey I'm a survivor and I have spent to many years worrying what people think. If cancer has taught me one thing its to be positive and do what's right for me and mine. So go on rock baby rock
Posts.Title: No headscarf

Posts.Content: Well done it's a great relief.  Be kind to yourself and check when you can start raising your arm vital for radiotherapy that may follow. It's doable and you've come so far onwards and upwards. Enjoy your cake. Pearl
Posts.Title: WLE and SNB, check!

Posts.Content: How lucky to have a daughter wanting to help. My sister has just finished chemo and radiotherapy I can only tell you what helped her. She was very sick after the first round of chemo and could keep nothing down. She ended up back in hospital where they managed to get everything under control. Her oncologist tweaked her medication and we had no more episodes like that one. The first few days she slept a lot and lived on ice cream and jelly babies but then she didn't lose her appetite and was soon eating normally again. She had a routine of wiping down all surfaces that were touched by hand with anti bacterial wipes/ kitchen roll soaked in anti bac spray. She did this every day and if she couldn't one of the family did it for her. Her husband has alkziemers so anti bac hand wash was used by both of them. A friend had also told her of a mouth wash called smile which again she used every day. Whether she was lucky or because she was so diligent she never picked up an infection and she didn't suffer with mouth ulcers. Her fear was that because her immune system was compromised she could catch an infection and be very poorly and her concern was for her husband she couldn't bear the thought of him going into care over night. Hope this helps and it seems daunting at first but one day at a time soon becomes the end of a journey. Wishing your mum and yourselves the strength and positivity mixed with a little humour to get you through this.
Posts.Title: preparing my mum for chemo

Posts.Content: Well papa smurf  I expect your out of theatre and relieved it's all done. I had my lumpectomy and sentinel node removal last year in April. Got to laugh as I was last down I came to on the bum ( bowel ) ward no offence meant. Because of this I feel I was discharged with no discussion relating to any excercises.  Due to this wonderful Web site I knew excercises were important so found some on cancer uk and contacted BCN to send out information. I understood I could do no damage so gradually built up the range of movement. So pleased I did as you need to raise your arm above your head for radiotherapy as they zapped the boob and underarm. It's doable but if your not sure talk to your BCN. Be kind to yourself and slowly build up the movement.  You may find a cushion under your arm will help with pain relief and is invaluable under a seat belt. I found the underarm area the most tender. The short sharp pangs are nerves healing know it will get better and any concerns you have you you can voice here. In answer to how often I did the excercises  if memory serves me right I believe I did them three times a day but would also raise my arm only several times during the day when watching TV.  Got fed up with hubby asking if I needed the loo!!!! Anyway hope this helps be kind to yourself  and listen to your body. Best wishes for a fast recovery.
Posts.Title: Exercises

Posts.Content: Brilliant I also saw the same news programme and what a fantastic idea. I thought others might like to know of another idea from usa for breast cancer patients recovering from surgery. I made heart shape cushions with cotton fabric and lightly stuffed them with approved toy stuffing worked a treat under the arm after auxiliary clearance and also were a godsend placed across the chest under the seat belt. It helped to be able to do something positive that helped not just me but others.I intend to knit and sew like crazy when I'm recovered to remember this roller coaster of a ride. Good luck to all out there keep strong.
Posts.Title: Knitted Knockers

Posts.Content: Hi Bunty-Ann I also had seromas after WLE and node clearance in fact I had it drained four times amazing how much fluid they got out of me! Anyway the fourth time I was sent to appliances where a lovely lady got me into a really strong tight bra come vest ( if your old enough a bit like a liberty bodice children wore in the 50's) I had to wear it day and night but it seemed to do the trick. Try asking your breast care nurse if that would help you. I understood it was training the fluid to go somewhere else anyway best of luck and hope it settles down soon. Xx
Posts.Title: Post Surgery Seroma Problems - Advice Please...

Posts.Content: Papa smurf it's early days yet. I had my lumpectomy  and nodes in April 2015 and can still get pain. This is the nerves settling down . We are all different and have different pain barriers but if you are at all concerned  talk to your breast care nurse. I had four seromas drained as fluid gathered under my armpit again doable and eventually the fluid moved on and was no longer a problem. I do know when I've done to to much as I can still feel sore under my arm like a paper cut ouch! I've also found that by nightfall my boob has swollen and taken on a square shape as though I have a Mars bar in there!! I do communicate with one of the girls who went through the same op at the same time as me and yes we compare notes and have found we are experiencing the same. A cushion under the arm really helps in the early days. Please know it will improve And be less painful with time. Best wishes for a speedy recovery..xx

Posts.Title: Discomfort increasing

Posts.Content: Hi so very scared you need to see someone who you feel can give you the confidence to accept there diagnosis. Have you seen a dermatologist?  I ask because because I became aware of a small red spot that would not go away. I had breast cancer 2015 and lumpectomy  radiation couldn't handle this spot at the same time!! So when treatment finished off to GP Refered to dermatology where they did a small biopsy and it turned out to be Bowens disease not cancerous but if left it could turn nasty. The critter came back so off to clinic been zapped twice so now it's gone. Yea so now I'm a pale and interesting English woman when I go on holiday factor 30or 40 sun cream it's doing the wrinkles a world of good. Please for your own peace of mind see someone who you feel can help and then get on with enjoying life. A day of worry is a day that could become yesterday don't take the worry to tomorrow.  Best wishes and hugs Pearl xx
Posts.Title: Please help I am so scared

Posts.Content: Oh oh been there got the t shirt well almost.  Had lumpectomy, node removal last year in April. Have had a mammogram no areas of concern. I did developed a very tender area and intermittent pain on the operated boob. Also had a slight swelling in my neck/collar bone area. Only thing to do get it checked out. The breast clinic fantastic appointment with consultant who said he thought there was nothing to worry about but for my peace of mind would request an ultrasound.  I'm fine it's scar tissue they were all very kind and they would rather see you about any concerns you have that's why they are there. To treat, help, reassure. Worry helps no one so go on pick up the phone. Hope it gets resolved sooner than later. Hugs pearlxxx
Posts.Title: Pain one year after surgery

Posts.Content: Hello Anne it's awful waiting isn't it? I'm also waiting for my results but here in the north east because they have been so busy I may have to wait 3-4 weeks!! I'm trying to be patient and not wind myself up to much but of course anxieties do creep in. I tell myself well if it is back I'll be able to do it again that the team is very good at targeting treatments where needed. Until I know I've resigned myself to keep busy and the biscuit tin unfortunately!  Good luck with your results and hope they arrive in the next few days.  Pearl
Posts.Title: Still waiting for mammogram results

Posts.Content: Hi tigg3 you are doing so well and have come so far. It's not surprising your tired it's quite a bit to get your head round. Your honestly not alone there are a lot of us who have been or are in the same situation. I found a smile and a cheery hello usually opened up conversations with others waiting for their appointment and it did help. Also fresh air and walking makes you feel better. Are you on any tablets that could perhaps make you feel low  do have a word with your nurse or oncologist if that's the case . Try and think positive you've had your op it's gone radiotherapy is your belt and braces not long now when your social life can return without hospital appointments apart from your yearly checks. So rest when you need to but celebrate how well you have done and enjoy the new you. By the way I was diagnosed 2015 had lumpectomy ,node removal and radiotherapy and I'm on exemestane tablets. Good days bad days but I give myself a good talking to when I feel down. Try and give yourself something to look forward to and if you need a hug well this site is here for you along with all of us who have come out the other side. I promise you'll look back on this and wonder how you did it and even forget bits of it. Onwards and upwards  Hugs Pearl
Posts.Title: Fatigue.

Posts.Content: Brilliant news it's a great relief. Get my second yearly check in April hopeful it means two years as a neddy. Onwards and upwards x
Posts.Title: It's been a year and I'm in the clear!

Posts.Content: Thank you for your reply I keep thinking ouch! on your behalf. I will pass your message on and my friends family can then decide what to do with the information.  I must admit I found it awful that this had to be paid for but hopefully I've raised the possibility that it may be charged for so no one is caught out. Posts.Title: Port line?

Posts.Content: jjtoo  Hi everyone, I'm still awaiting date for surgery (probable WLE & sentinel node biopsy, but that may change depending on what last Friday's MRI showed), but can anyone tell me would an hour long Bus trip home the next day be doable?  Also, were there things you found hard to do afterwards that you didn't expect?  have you heard of the charity daft as a brush they work in the northumberland  region and are there to help people get to and from hospital. They may work in other regions worth asking or go ogling maggie centres may be able to offer advice. I would definitely let friends and neighbours  know the situation give them a chance to help and understand you may be surprised how kind people can be. Also you may be surprised that some off them have been where you are now and are survivors. It's being kind to your self to accept help when needed. I found I needed to protect my arm and boob on the journey home with a cushion. The under arm is the worst and does limit what you can do for a short while. I'm no wimp but found after doing the excercises felt quite exhausted  we are all different listen to your body and don't let your independence hold you back from asking for help if you need it wishing you a good outcome and fast recovery. It's all doable and yes we are stronger than we know. Ironing for awhile took a back seat just looked slightly creased ha ha
Posts.Title: Bus home after surgery?

Posts.Content: Hi Janey so sorry your finding it difficult  at the moment. I think we all have times when our fears get the better of us and believe me your not alone. I find if I talk to my inner self it helps to believe the oncologist and surgeons know what they are dealing with and have taken the best course for a good outcome. Remember more people survive breast cancer these days than in the past. I'm sorry about your mum and of course your anxiety is understandable.  Perhaps have a word with your nurse and she can refer you to counselling which may help you to get your head around it. You've been brave and strong you now just have to believe you can survive this . Sending hugs and positive thoughts your way.
Posts.Title: Worried!

Posts.Content: It's such a huge relief isn't it. That letter that says no evidence of disease is magic. Welcome to the nedy club now breathe.  Pearl
Posts.Title: Phew!

Posts.Content: Hi ayres1962 welcome to the club we all try and support where we can. Try and keep busy it helps us stop imagining the worst.  We've all done it but your doing the right thing getting checked and putting your mind at rest. I want to say scary though it is breast cancer is very very treatable these days. I was diagnosed 2015 had a lumpectomy  lymph nodes removed Radiation and have a mammogram every year and there are no areas of concern. Please take someone with you as you can miss what's been said through sheer anxiety and it would be awful if you missed the words no reason for concern. Besides gives you the excuse to indulge in a bit of cake or retail therapy.  Wishing you the best outcome but know if you need us we are all here to help. You don't hear about the outcome of people still here after 18 or 20 years. So courage my friend and hopefully it is just muscle strain Hugs pearl xx
Posts.Title: Pains shoulder blade

Posts.Content: Hi salley poor you it does resolve itself in time. I had a seroma drained three times and then I was given an " appliance" Wasn't sure what to expect turned out to be a front fastening bra extremely tight which I had to wear morning and night. Think the liquid finally got the message and found new routes. Gentle massage can help to move the fluid on . Please ask your nurse what can be done to encourage the drainage to other areas. Also ask for stronger pain killers if you feel you need them. Co codomol is very strong but can cause constipation and in some cases can be addictive if taken to long. On an upward message it does get better my mum had a great saying nothing lasts for ever the bad times do pass. Look how far you have come all ready you will get through this. I'm three years post op and would you believe some of its a bit blurry and I have my life back. Onwards and upwards.  Pearl

Posts.Title: Seroma/ pain

Posts.Content: Would just like to add that it's a good idea to have a soft cushion to place on the chest area for coming home as seat belts seem to catch the operation site. Ouch!! Also good to go under arm if having node clearance.  Excercises are very important for the arm movement as we need to raise our arms above our head in case we need further treatment of radiotherapy. I didn't receive any instructions for excercises but knew I needed to do them and managed to ask breast care nurse about them who forwarded the excercises to me. Have to say I may have been missed as I ended up on a different ward ( the bowel ward) after my lumpectomy and node removal. No heavy lifting and let hoovering ,ironing etc take a bit of a back seat for awhile. Sometimes people are sent home with drains not alarming just bloody awkward as they are like milk bottles at the end of tubes some people carry them in soft shoulder bags. Again it's only for a short time I only had one drain which was removed the next day before I went home. This site is brilliant for answers to many questions there's usually someone to answer And of course your breast care nurse can be contacted. I found if I rang in the morning someone would get back to me By the afternoon. What a lovely niece you are it's not an easy journey but it is doable wishing you and your aunt a successful outcome and a quick recovery . Onwards and upwards  Pearlxx
Posts.Title: Care after Surgery
